perturbation.original_text: The relevant assignee Party shall have the sole responsibility, at its sole cost and expense, to file the Intellectual Property Assignment Agreements and any other forms or documents with the appropriate Governmental Authorities as required to record the transfer of any registrations or applications of Nuance IP or SpinCo IP that is allocated under the Separation Agreement, as applicable, and the relevant assignor Party hereby consents to such recordation.
perturbation.changed_text: The relevant assignee Party shall endeavor to file the Intellectual Property Assignment Agreements and any other forms or documents with Governmental Authorities, as it deems reasonably appropriate to record the transfer of registrations or applications of Nuance IP or SpinCo IP that is allocated under the Separation Agreement, as applicable, and the relevant assignor Party hereby consents to such recordation.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces ambiguity by replacing 'shall have the sole responsibility' with 'shall endeavor,' which weakens the obligation to file. Also, replacing 'as required' with 'as it deems reasonably appropriate' introduces discretion, potentially leading to non-compliance. By using the word "endeavor" instead of "shall", it is not clearly stating an obligation to fulfill the recordation of the IP rights assignment, which is a legal contradiction. The wording introduces ambiguity, conflicting with the requirements for intellectual property assignments.
perturbation.law_explanation: The Lanham Act states the assignment must be recorded in the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO). The modified text uses 'endeavor' and 'deems reasonably appropriate', which creates discretion on whether to record the assignment. If it isn't recorded, this violates the Lanham Act.

perturbation.original_text: SpinCo agrees that it will not (i) oppose, challenge, petition to cancel, contest or threaten in any way, or assist another party in opposing, challenging, petitioning to cancel, contesting or threatening in any way, any application or registration by Nuance or its Affiliates or their respective licensees for any Nuance IP, (ii) engage in any act, or purposefully omit to perform any act, that impairs or adversely affects the rights of Nuance or any member of the Nuance Group in and to any Nuance IP or (iii) apply for any registration (including federal, state and national registrations) with respect to the Nuance IP.
perturbation.changed_text: SpinCo agrees that it will generally not (i) oppose, challenge, petition to cancel, contest or threaten in any way, or assist another party in opposing, challenging, petitioning to cancel, contesting or threatening in any way, any application or registration by Nuance or its Affiliates or their respective licensees for any Nuance IP, (ii) engage in any act, or make commercially reasonable efforts to avoid purposefully omitting to perform any act, that impairs or adversely affects the rights of Nuance or any member of the Nuance Group in and to any Nuance IP or (iii) apply for any registration (including federal, state and national registrations) with respect to the Nuance IP unless compelled by law.
perturbation.explanation: By adding "generally not" and "commercially reasonable efforts" the language weakens SpinCo's commitment not to challenge Nuance's IP and not to impair Nuance's IP rights. Also, by adding "unless compelled by law" it allows SpinCo to apply for registration of Nuance IP if a law exists that requires them to do so. These additions introduce ambiguity that opens the door for SpinCo to challenge or undermine Nuance's IP rights. This contradicts common law legal precedent.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common law, including precedent set in cases regarding fiduciary duty and implied covenants of good faith and fair dealing.
perturbation.law_citation: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.
perturbation.law_explanation: This modification introduces ambiguity, potentially violating the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing present in most contracts under common law. This covenant requires parties to act honestly and not undermine the purpose of the contract. The changes allow SpinCo to take actions that could harm Nuance's IP rights, contradicting this principle.

perturbation.original_text: In addition to the actions specifically provided for elsewhere in this Agreement, each of the Parties shall use reasonable best efforts, prior to, on and after the Distribution Date, to take, or cause to be taken, all actions, and to do, or cause to be done, all things, reasonably necessary, proper or advisable under applicable Laws and agreements to consummate, and make effective, the transactions contemplated by this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: In addition to the actions specifically provided for elsewhere in this Agreement, each of the Parties shall use reasonable efforts, prior to, on and after the Distribution Date, to take actions, and to do things, reasonably necessary, proper or advisable under applicable Laws and agreements to consummate, and make effective, the transactions contemplated by this Agreement, provided that such actions do not result in undue hardship.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "reasonable best efforts" to "reasonable efforts" weakens the obligation. The clause "provided that such actions do not result in undue hardship" gives each party an out if they deem the effort required to be too burdensome. This introduces subjectivity and could allow a party to avoid fulfilling the intended purpose of the agreement.
perturbation.law_explanation: DGCL § 141(a) mandates that the business and affairs of a Delaware corporation are managed by or under the direction of a board of directors, and they are required to act in good faith and with the care that an ordinarily prudent person would exercise under similar circumstances. The "undue hardship" clause creates an incentive to shirk responsibility. The phrase "undue hardship" can be interpreted in many different ways, which violates the DGCL's duty of care.
